content.description: Chalky and soft on first few easy moves then getting to much better rock. Includes a little ofwidth but mostly hands and stemming. Very fun, good pro.
content.protection: Doubles fingers size through #4 and one #5. No bolts but bring a few draws and extenders to cut down on rope drag
content.location: 30 feet right of Ed. Starts on big hands to double crack then around small roof to a ledge below a chimney goes another 10 feet to a second, larger ledge with a nice overlook of the canyon. Two bolt anchor with Mussy hooks.

content.description: Start slightly right from sandy bottom then traverse left on rail to start of crack. Clip first bolt then grit your teeth and move through the technical crux, very thin past 2nd bolt then into crack with nice gear. Crack is hands and fingers, sometimes shallow, sometimes flaring. Some really hard crack toward top then over mini roof to great edges and 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 2 bolts, nuts, triples from tiny stuff to .75BD, 00 and 0 metolious great, even ball nuts useful, singles from 1 to 3BD, a #4 is useful for start of crack. Great to have your small stuff in diff cam types for overlap in range.
content.location: In the same alcove as Dirty mcnasty's, right side of john doe wall as you follow the base right and down/around a bit.

content.description: Obvious spectacular offwidth on right side of JD wall. P1: Climb moderate but fun low angle crack to bolted belay. P2 and P3 make your way up wonderful chicken wings and knee jams for a little over 200 feet to top anchor. Rap back down route
content.protection: for first pitch you need a standard assortment including singles BD .5 through #4, nuts won't likely be used. Pitches 2 and 3 require one #4 two #5, and two #6's. There are 4 bolts. This helps to avoid just sliding the big cams and depending on only one or two pieces between you and the belayer. Pitch one is funner that it looks, with a cool finish. Pitches 2 and 3 are fantastic every step of the way, getting better the higher you go. Good rock and very low choss factor on the offwidth. Classic route - do it!

content.description: IT's not dirty or nasty, it's really good. Only 45 feet long but it's a really sweet hand crack with superb features, great hand and foot jams the whole way to anchor.
content.location: Starting at base of JD wall, walk to your right, past Jane Doe down a bit and around an adjoining wall. Bushwack and follow base of the wall until you can walk up a short gully to an opening. McNasty's is the obvious handcrack on right side of gully.

content.description: Obvious long offwidth on the left side of the wall. Start below and left of the offwidth crack at 15 foot chimney split on both sides. Travel over broken and chossy stuff up and traversing right around a corner. This first pitch is a traversing, chossy mess that is like 5.7. It's just to access the sweet crack above. Once at the crack you'll start having fun immediately, on mostly good rock. You will end up at a roomy alcove below top of wall. You may ascent cracks to top then scramble back to alcove through steep gulley.  The offwidth section has good and interesting rock, worth the crappy first pitch.The last pitch is good rock with stemming and jugs everywhere. Rap the slung boulder then two more raps. straight down.
content.protection: Mostly larger gear. Full rack of cams and nuts with doubles on 3.5 through 5. triples #4 is better.

content.description: First two pitches are among the best I've ever done, and the third pitch is pretty good too!   Easy 4th class 30ft up slabs to base of short dihedral. Clip a bolt and pendulum left (or stretch left for free-11b height dependent variation) then up hand and finger crack to anchor (90ft including slabs) P2: this pitch has everything! technical finger crux off the belay then thru a pod to a difficult obtuse chimney to a roof with good jams! (80ft) P3; up corner/chimney past a few bulges and big jams then stem over out over space and follow OW with face edges to an inspiring vista from an alcove.(95ft)
content.protection: you can get away with singles to #5 camalot including a #4.5 but you may want a few doubles (#2,#3,#4); also useful at start of P2 one gold LoweBallNut (regular small nuts will work though)
content.location: center fo the John Doe Wall

content.description: A 300-350 foot sandstone wall with some nice cracks
